snippet: In Afghanistan, a growing uproar over ethnicity — Pashtun, Tajik, Hazara and Uzbek — has many concerned about possible violence, especially those who remember the country’s civil war.
abstract: Many Afghans, with American-led coalition about to withdraw and long-term security agreement in doubt, feel vulnerable about the growing ethnic uproar between the Pashtun, Tajik, Hazara and Uzbek; shouting matches over ethnic issues in Parliament and on radio programs have started to erupt into fistfights, but so far ordinary Afghans, many of whom remember the country's civil war, do not seem to be following their lead and are even protesting the provocations.

byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI

lead_paragraph: In Afghanistan, a growing uproar over ethnicity — Pashtun, Tajik, Hazara and Uzbek — has many concerned about possible violence, especially those who remember the country’s civil war.

headline.main: Afghan Ethnic Tensions Rise in Media and Politics
